bibl.title: A Greek-Aramaic Silver Amulet from Egypt in the Ashmolean Museum.
bibl.note: Inv. 1921.1121. Thin sheet of silver (12 X 6 cm), once folded into a tiny, compact square. Evidence of fire suggests that the amulet formed part of a cremation burial. The tablet preserves a Jewish exorcism of evil spirits and fever from John, son of Benenata. Tell el-Amarna, probably 5th century A.D.
bibl.seg: KOTANSKY Roy, J. NAVEH and S. SHAKED, A Greek-Aramaic Silver Amulet from Egypt in the Ashmolean Museum.

Inv. 1921.1121. Thin sheet of silver (12 X 6 cm), once folded into a tiny, compact square. Evidence of fire suggests that the amulet formed part of a cremation burial. The tablet preserves a Jewish exorcism of evil spirits and fever from John, son of Benenata. Tell el-Amarna, probably 5th century A.D.
